Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: What drives speciation in Nearctic aphids?
Award.AbstractNarration:
One out of every three species of insects is a plant-eating insect, but most plant-eating insect species feed on only a few plant species. Although this phenomenon is clearly relevant for basic and applied biology, it is currently not well understood. This project addresses this issue by exploring patterns of biological diversity in the sap-sucking bug species of North America. Specifically, it tests the idea that both the high species diversity and the narrow diets of plant-eating insects are the result of co-evolutionary interactions with plants. These interactions are analogous to an arms race; plants evolve diverse defenses against plant-eating insects, which, in turn, evolve diverse (and specific) ways of overcoming those defenses. This idea has been central to explanations of plant-eating insect diversity for more than half a century. But until recently, researchers have lacked the resources to test it. This project will pull together those resources, and give us an unprecedented opportunity to advance our understanding of the forces that generate biological diversity. This project will provide education and training opportunities for biology students and instructors at multiple career levels, and from multiple backgrounds.Â The goal is to train biodiversity scientists, and to improve access to biodiversity science for underrepresented groups.

This project aims to identify ecological factors that drive host-use evolution and speciation in plant-eating insects. It uses Nearctic aphids as a model system and has three objectives: 1) Use DNA sequence data to estimate phylogenetic relationships among ~500 aphid species. 2) Use more than a quarter of a million specimen records and the primary research literature to characterize the niche of each Nearctic aphid species. 3) Use comparative statistical analyses to test hypotheses about the evolution of aphid species and niches. Corollary objectives are to improve aphid systematics and gain insights into the general evolutionary processes that beget biodiversity. This research may enable researchers to gain insights into economically important aspects of aphid biology, such as disease vector capacity and invasiveness. In turn, these may lead to better strategies for excluding and controlling aphid populations, which could increase the efficiency and sustainability of U.S. agriculture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One out of every three species is an herbivorous insect. Why are they so diverse? In this project, we addressed this question with statistical analyses of how various ecological factors affect species accumulation in aphids. For most groups of living things, scientists tend to think of speciation as a primarily geographic process; speciation is what happens when two parts of a population become physically isolated. In contrast, classical ideas about the species diversification of herbivorous insects have hinged on antagonistic coevolution with their host plants. We tested those ideas.

We found evidence that host-use evolution does indeed drive speciation in aphids. But so too does divergence in other aspects of an aphid species' ecology; it seems that aphid speciation entails a mix of geographic isolation and divergent selection on host-use. Moreover, host-use divergence may tend to push for speciation in ways other than what is envisioned in classical theory of antagonistic coevolution. The classical theory postulates bouts of adaptive radiation: when an herbivorous insect lineages evolves a way of overcoming a set of plant defenses, it enters a realm of ecological opportunity, and undergoes rapid niche and species diversification within that realm. But our analyses suggest that this is not how it typically happens; host-use evolution is less constrained, and it is the overall rates at which host-use and diet breadth evolve that predict rates of speciation.

This project increased participation in biodiversity science. It provided support for two graduate students and two seventh grade life-science teachers working in under-served communities in rural Alabama. It enhances the capacity of those teachers to teach evolution and ecology, and it let us develop and deliver two two-day programs about the scope and value of insect diversity to fifty of their students, almost all of whom are members of under-represented minority groups. It also provided high-impact learning opportunities for about twenty entomology graduate students, who were able to apply what they had learned about insect diversity to develop activities for our programs for seventh graders.

Our insights from this project have practical applications in agriculture. As we seek to develop more productive and sustainable farming practices, many of our greatest challenges pertain to herbivorous insect evolution. What we have learned about the evolution of the interactions between herbivorous insects and their host plants in nature sheds light on the evolution that takes place on farms. As an illustration, as part of this project, we showed that an herbivorous insect's evolutionary history of host use is a powerful predictor of insecticide resistance evolution. Thus, this research has the potential for broad positive impacts across society.
